articles.headline: F.D.A. Steps Up Oversight of Infusion Pumps
articles.snippet: Infusion pumps, used to deliver medicines into a patient’s body, have been linked to 710 deaths in five years.
articles.abstract: Infusion pumps, used to deliver medicines into a patient’s body, have been linked to 710 deaths in five years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators say they are moving to tighten their oversight of medical devices, including one of the most ubiquitous and problematic pieces of medical equipment — automated pumps that intravenously deliver drugs, food and other solutions to patients.

articles.headline: Arizona Enacts Stringent Law on Immigration
articles.snippet: Gov. Jan Brewer signed a bill aimed at identifying, prosecuting and deporting illegal immigrants.
articles.abstract: Gov. Jan Brewer signed a bill aimed at identifying, prosecuting and deporting illegal immigrants.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona signed the nation’s toughest bill on illegal immigration into law on Friday. Its aim is to identify, prosecute and deport illegal immigrants.

articles.headline: Chinese Military Seeks to Extend Its Naval Power
articles.snippet: China wants warships to escort vessels crucial to the country’s economy, from the Pacific to the Middle East.
articles.abstract: China wants warships to escort vessels crucial to the country’s economy, from the Pacific to the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: YALONG BAY, China — The Chinese military is seeking to project naval power well beyond the Chinese coast, from the oil ports of the Middle East to the shipping lanes of the Pacific, where the United States Navy has long reigned as the dominant force, military officials and analysts say.

articles.headline: Financial Advice by Women for Women
articles.snippet: Money advice is universal, but some issues affect women more than men. Experts also say women tend to be less knowledgeable and confident about finances.
articles.abstract: Money advice is universal, but some issues affect women more than men. Experts also say women tend to be less knowledgeable and confident about finances.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several personal finance books aimed at women landed in my mailbox recently. They were hard to miss. The books had pink covers and the catchy, if cringeworthy, titles, “Shoo, Jimmy Choo!” and “Hot (Broke) Messes.” And then there was the one I found on Amazon, “A Purse of Your Own.”

articles.headline: C.D.O. Days, S&M Nights at Derivatives Conference
articles.snippet: The call for sweeping regulation put a cloud over an annual derivatives conference in San Francisco.
articles.abstract: The call for sweeping regulation put a cloud over an annual derivatives conference in San Francisco.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — By day, they dealt with risk. At night, it got risqué.

articles.headline: Coney Island Getting a $30 Million Italian Makeover
articles.snippet: Alberto Zamperla, whose family has been building amusement park attractions for 40 years, is refurbishing the famous park.
articles.abstract: Alberto Zamperla, whose family has been building amusement park attractions for 40 years, is refurbishing the famous park.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALTAVILLA VICENTINA, Italy — Alberto Zamperla sweeps through the cavernous workshop here where his amusement rides are manufactured while workers measure and bang and solder enormous platforms, oddly shaped beams and assorted fiberglass vehicles.

articles.headline: Don’t Call It ‘Pot’ in This Circle; It’s a Profession
articles.snippet: Backers of medical marijuana are trying to professionalize both the business and the image of pot.
articles.abstract: Backers of medical marijuana are trying to professionalize both the business and the image of pot.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Like hip-hop, health food and snowboarding, marijuana is going corporate.

articles.headline: Greece, Out of Ideas, Requests Global Aid
articles.snippet: The country is expected to get help from the International Monetary Fund, but an aid package from Greece’s euro zone partners could test the Continent’s solidarity.
articles.abstract: The country is expected to get help from the International Monetary Fund, but an aid package from Greece’s euro zone partners could test the Continent’s solidarity.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Describing his country’s economy as “a sinking ship,” Greece’s prime minister formally requested an international bailout on Friday, creating the biggest test so far to the European monetary union.
articles.byline: By Niki Kitsantonis and Matthew Saltmarsh

articles.headline: Rating Agency Data Aided Wall Street in Deals
articles.snippet:
Trying to be transparent, credit rating agencies made
their computer models public, and banks used that knowledge to shape some of the investments involved in the financial crisis.
articles.abstract:
Trying to be transparent, credit rating agencies made
their computer models public, and banks used that knowledge to shape some of the investments involved in the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the mysteries of the financial crisis is how mortgage investments that turned out to be so bad earned credit ratings that made them look so good.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Louise Story

articles.headline: Learning How to Fight the Collector
articles.snippet: A small but growing number of lawyers and consumers are fighting back against bill collectors and violations of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act.
articles.abstract: A small but growing number of lawyers and consumers are fighting back against bill collectors and violations of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: Among debt collectors, Steven Katz is known as a “credit terrorist.” For years, he has run what he calls the Steven Katz School of Bill Collector Education, otherwise known as the “credit terrorist training camp.”

articles.headline: Goldman Cited ‘Serious’ Profit on Mortgages
articles.snippet: A Senate panel released messages Goldman Sachs executives sent in 2007 that appear to contradict its suggestion that it lost money on the housing market.
articles.abstract: A Senate panel released messages Goldman Sachs executives sent in 2007 that appear to contradict its suggestion that it lost money on the housing market.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late 2007, as the mortgage crisis gained momentum and many banks were suffering losses, Goldman Sachs executives traded e-mail messages saying that they would make “some serious money” betting against the housing markets.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Sewell Chan

articles.headline: Vegas Mob Museums, Set to Go to the Mattresses
articles.snippet: Dueling centers chronicling the history of organized crime are set to open in Las Vegas within a year of each other.
articles.abstract: Dueling centers chronicling the history of organized crime are set to open in Las Vegas within a year of each other.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The people of Chicago debate the Cubs versus the White Sox. In Philadelphia, the cheese steak purveyors Pat’s and Geno’s have long divided the citizenry. Soon, the residents of Las Vegas — and the millions of people who visit — will be able to argue over which museum best depicts the moral turpitude of organized crime.

articles.headline: Calling Almost Everyone’s Tune
articles.snippet: Live Nation Entertainment, the combination of Live Nation and Ticketmaster, is a colossus unlike anything the music industry has ever seen.
articles.abstract: Live Nation Entertainment, the combination of Live Nation and Ticketmaster, is a colossus unlike anything the music industry has ever seen.
articles.lead_paragraph: “It’s tough to handle this fortune and fame.

articles.headline: Democrats’ Long-Held Seats Face G.O.P. Threat
articles.snippet: The fight for the midterm elections is not confined to traditional battlegrounds as voter discontent surges, threatening Democratic control of Congress.
articles.abstract: The fight for the midterm elections is not confined to traditional battlegrounds as voter discontent surges, threatening Democratic control of Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASHLAND, Wis. — Representative David R. Obey has won 21 straight races, easily prevailing through wars and economic crises that have spanned presidencies from Nixon’s to Obama’s. Yet the discontent with Washington surging through politics is now threatening not only his seat but also Democratic control of Congress.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: Do You Have Any Reforms in Size XL?
articles.snippet: Financial reform is gaining traction in Congress, but the leading proposals would create a system with big advantages for the largest banks.
articles.abstract: Financial reform is gaining traction in Congress, but the leading proposals would create a system with big advantages for the largest banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERY once in a while, Congress awakens from its lobbyist-induced torpor, realizes that the masses are cranky and sets out to appease them. Such a moment occurred last week when lawmakers finally got the message that Main Street is disgusted with Wall Street and wants them to do something about it.

articles.headline: Democrats, Pressuring G.O.P., Unite on Finance Bill
articles.snippet: A deal among Democrats on derivatives raised the pressure on Senate Republicans, who said they were still fighting for changes to the bill.
articles.abstract: A deal among Democrats on derivatives raised the pressure on Senate Republicans, who said they were still fighting for changes to the bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats said Sunday that they had bridged internal party differences and coalesced around a plan to tighten regulation of derivatives, the complex financial instruments that were a major factor in the 2008 economic crisis.

articles.headline: Elite U.S. Units Step Up Effort in Afghan City Before Attack
articles.snippet: Elite forces are picking off insurgents to weaken the Taliban as the looming battle for Kandahar is shaping up as the pivotal test of President Obama’s Afghanistan strategy.
articles.abstract: Elite forces are picking off insurgents to weaken the Taliban as the looming battle for Kandahar is shaping up as the pivotal test of President Obama’s Afghanistan strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Thom Shanker, Helene Cooper and Richard A. Oppel Jr.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker, Helene Cooper and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: A Rebuilding Phase for Independent Film
articles.snippet: The indie scene is getting a boost from fleet-footed, penny-pinching guerrilla operations that are trying to resuscitate the business.
articles.abstract: The indie scene is getting a boost from fleet-footed, penny-pinching guerrilla operations that are trying to resuscitate the business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only five years ago, the center of the still thriving independent film universe lay behind the green doors of a converted TriBeCa warehouse from which the Weinstein brothers, Bob and Harvey, ran Miramax Films.

articles.headline: Monetizing an iPhone Spectacle
articles.snippet: When the gadget blog Gizmodo paid $5,000 for an iPhone prototype, questions were raised about publishers providing money for information.
articles.abstract: When the gadget blog Gizmodo paid $5,000 for an iPhone prototype, questions were raised about publishers providing money for information.
articles.lead_paragraph: We all know that advertisers need to pay for clicks to keep the Web spinning. But what does it mean when publishers start paying for them as well?

articles.headline: Sex Ads Seen Adding Revenue to Craigslist
articles.snippet: Law enforcement officials say the ads, expected to bring $36 million this year, are still being used for prostitution.
articles.abstract: Law enforcement officials say the ads, expected to bring $36 million this year, are still being used for prostitution.
articles.lead_paragraph: Craigslist, one of the most popular Web sites in the United States, is on track to increase its revenue 22 percent this year, largely from its controversial sex advertisements. That financial success is reviving scrutiny from law-enforcement officials who say the ads are still being used for illegal ends.

articles.headline: Investigation Links Critic’s Death to Top Chechens
articles.snippet: New evidence is raising questions about whether Chechnya’s president played a role in the killing of a whistleblower who was gunned down in 2009.
articles.abstract: New evidence is raising questions about whether Chechnya’s president played a role in the killing of a whistleblower who was gunned down in 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Umar S. Israilov, a whistleblower living in hiding after accusing Chechnya’s president of personally participating in torture, kidnapping and murder, was gunned down here last year as he stepped from a grocery store with yogurt, eggs and bags of M&M’s and Gummi Bears for his three young children.

articles.headline: From the Mall to the Docks, Signs of Rebound
articles.snippet: While few dispute signs of recovery across much of the U.S. economy, significant debate remains on how robust and sustained it will be.
articles.abstract: While few dispute signs of recovery across much of the U.S. economy, significant debate remains on how robust and sustained it will be.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The docks are humming again at this sprawling Pacific port, with clouds of golden dust billowing off the piles of grain spilling into the bellies of giant tankers.

articles.headline: United and Continental Merger Talks Said to Stall
articles.snippet: In a stock-for-stock deal, how the shares are priced goes to the heart of the value of the transaction.
articles.abstract: In a stock-for-stock deal, how the shares are priced goes to the heart of the value of the transaction.
articles.lead_paragraph: Merger talks between United Airlines and Continental Airlines reached an impasse over the weekend over a disagreement about the price of a deal, people involved in the negotiations said on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: An Uneasy Marriage of the Cultish and the Rumpled
articles.snippet: At Bloomberg News, Businessweek is fitting in like an 80-year-old print magazine in a company that is all about terminals.
articles.abstract: At Bloomberg News, Businessweek is fitting in like an 80-year-old print magazine in a company that is all about terminals.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Bloomberg L.P. bought Businessweek in December, a group of the magazine’s writers, who were being transferred to the Bloomberg newswire, attended a two-week training session. They learned that the terminals, costing about $20,000 a year, drove Bloomberg’s business; they discovered that the main elevators stop only on the sixth and ninth floors, forcing a manic feeling in the building as employees dash up and down staircases.

articles.headline: Best Hope for Greece: Minimize the Losses
articles.snippet: Spreading out payments to creditors, who would have to accept a decline in the value of their investments, is starting to look good among many bad choices.
articles.abstract: Spreading out payments to creditors, who would have to accept a decline in the value of their investments, is starting to look good among many bad choices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only a few weeks ago, the idea that Greece might restructure its debt seemed like the nuclear option. Now restructuring — a polite alternative to outright “default” — is not only thinkable, but even likely.

articles.headline: Election Ruling in Iraq Favors Prime Minister
articles.snippet: A parliamentary candidate was disqualified, most likely reversing the defeat of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s alliance, in a move that could delay the formation of a new government.
articles.abstract: A parliamentary candidate was disqualified, most likely reversing the defeat of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s alliance, in a move that could delay the formation of a new government.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Seven weeks after Iraqis went to the polls, a special elections court disqualified a winning parliamentary candidate, most likely reversing the narrow defeat of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s alliance and possibly allowing him the first chance to form a new coalition government.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Sam Dagher
